courseDescription: The fundamentals of the managerial process (planning, organizing, leading and controlling) are considered in the context of 21st century organizations. Topics are almost evenly split between macro and micro perspectives
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to plan, organize, lead and control in digital context
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration within a modern organizational structure
Effective communication in a managerial role
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical evaluation of macro and micro perspectives
Ability to plan and control within an organization
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing within an organization

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the importance and centrality of communication in business. Students will learn the application of business communication principles by working both individually and collaboratively on communicating through effective business documents, presentations, professional written and oral correspondence, and use of digital media. Attention will be given to both interpersonal and group audiences, as well as formal and informal delivery.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital media for communication
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading communication efforts in business contexts

courseDescription: This class examines theories and concepts pertaining to people at work. Topics include personality differences, motivation principles, high-performing work teams, and leadership development.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying components of high-performing work teams

courseDescription: This course provides students knowledge of fundamental issues and opportunities facing entrepreneurial ventures on the global stage. Students are exposed to core theories, contemporary trends, and cutting-edge research in international entrepreneurship. Students will examine what motivates entrepreneurs to seek foreign markets, and how to leverage cultural differences.  The course discusses frameworks to analyze key factors and risks involved with venturing abroad, and assessing the strategies and resources needed for international success.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills for global market trends

courseDescription: This class examines all issues pertaining to managing people in an organization. Topics include strategic planning for Human Resources, recruitment and selection systems, performance evaluation and development programs, Equal Employment Opportunity, and diversity management.

Examines personnel topics such as absenteeism, substance abuse, theft, gambling and counseling problem employees.  Policies and practices used by organizations to anticipate and resolve these problems are explored and evaluated.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Detection and Mitigation of Employee Misconduct
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementation of Organizational Policies and Practices

courseDescription: A contextual study of the trade union movement and its development, structure and processes.  Emphasizes the impact of union organization on management practice and effectiveness in both private and public sector organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of public and private sector organizations
Familiarity with union organization impact on management
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with different levels of management
Interacting with public and private sector organizations

courseDescription: An examination of the environment of multinational business, foreign trade, and the operation of multinational enterprises.  Management, marketing, accounting, and financial problems unique to enterprises operating in varying economic, cultural, and political legal environments are investigated. This course includes a CAP experience.  International business majors may not take MGMT 361 for credit.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of unique management, marketing, accounting, and financial problems in international business
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication across diverse cultural and political landscapes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of international business management problems
Problem-solving in diverse economic, cultural, and legal contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational management in diverse economic and cultural environments

courseDescription: May be repeated for credit. Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with department and Career Development Services
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of academic knowledge to work scenarios

courseDescription: Approval for enrollment and allowable credits is determined by the department and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  (qualifies as a CAP experience)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting with department and Career Development Services
Effective communication in a professional setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and implementing feedback from supervisors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Handling responsibilities and tasks in a professional setting

courseDescription: Approval for enrollment is determined by the Management CAP advisor and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment.  Student will participate in a relevant work setting.  (qualifies as a CAP experience)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a professional setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a practical work setting
Adapting leadership styles to different scenarios

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of leadership as a phenomenon impacting individuals, organizations, and the larger society. Major leadership theories are examined along with processes through which leadership influences various internal and external organizational factors. Leadership traits, behaviors, styles, communication, and the dynamic nature of leader-follower developments will be addressed. Methods of instruction include case studies, experiential exercises, and simulations.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying major leadership theories
Adapting leadership traits, behaviors, and styles
Understanding the impact of leadership on organizations

courseDescription: An analysis of how the federal and state governments may regulate the employer-employee relationship.  Topics include labor relations law, equal employment opportunity law, other current statutory employment law and common law employment issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of equal employment opportunity law
Familiarity with current statutory employment law
Comprehension of common law employment issues

courseTitle: Advanced Human Resource Management: Contemporary Issues
courseDescription: An in-depth analysis of current issues and concerns within human resources management. The course will focus on specific issues and problems associated with the law and equal employment opportunity, employee selection, training and development, performance management/appraisal, and compensation.  Methods of instruction include cases, exercises and PC applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of HR laws and equal employment opportunity

courseDescription: Course focuses on assessing the strategies, tactics, dilemmas, processes and solutions associated with developing a new business. Emphasis is devoted to how new ventures should raise rates (sales, prices, productivity), decrease costs, promote and execute while pursuing innovation. The course explores a wide variety of actual small business case studies to illuminate the critical strategic, operational and behavioral considerations necessary to build a successful enterprise, including rollouts (duplicating a business model in multiple locations), rollups (acquiring similar businesses to accelerate growth), and franchises.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational strategy for business rollouts, rollups and franchises
Leadership in small business case study analysis

courseDescription: This course focuses on three core elements of managing innovation and technology in small and large organizations. First, it teaches in-depth analysis of how innovations can transform companies and industries, including who gains and loses from such developments. Second, it explains how organizations can organize to create innovations internally and externally, and how they can take advantage of opportunities while mitigating threats in technology and innovation development. Third, it discusses how firms benefit and prosper by using various methods of commercialization and protecting new technologies and innovation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying opportunities and threats in technology development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing for internal and external innovation

courseDescription: A study of the essential elements leading to entrepreneurial and intrapreneurial success with emphasis on the creation, structure and management of new ventures.  A recommended elective for business students.

An examination of the relationship between business (usually the individual firm, but occasionally a group of firms in an industry or a set of headline-makers in different industries) and society (an individual, group of people, the general public, or government entity representing the interests of this individual or group or the public).  Emphasizes stakeholders and ethics.  The course material is both philosophical and practical for executives and informative and practical for citizens.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of business impacts on society

courseDescription: This class examines issues pertaining to developing, evaluating, and re-designing an organization's direct and indirect compensation systems. Topics include pay structure, incentive plans, benefit programs, and special cases such as executive compensation.

This course examines both research and practice regarding the strategic recruitment, selection, and development of top talent in organizations. Discussion topics include understanding and planning for talent needs, use of current recruitment methods and selection techniques, development of both internal and external talent pools, and the influences of external and internal changes due to competitive business environments and job design/redesign initiatives. The strategic and legal context of employment decision making is emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and planning for talent needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation to external and internal changes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Legal context of employment decision making

courseDescription: The role of performance management (PM) systems (performance measurement, appraisal, and development) is critical to organizational and workers success. This course focuses on how an effective PM system created in alignment with an organization’s strategy, mission, values, and product or services, can attract, develop, and retain top-performers. We will discuss how PM systems are tied to reward systems and will examine the legal regulations to which an organization must adhere. Topics include performance appraisals, coaching, feedback, reward systems, and related management activities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of legal regulations for performance management
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Alignment of PM system with organizational strategy, mission, and values

courseDescription: This course focuses on negotiations and change. Students will develop analytical, interpersonal, and communication skills, with an emphasis placed on experiential learning through case studies, role playing, and simulations.

This course provides an introduction to the use of people analytics to optimize HR processes. Students will learn about human resource analytics tools, technologies, and tasks. Topics include: modeling employee turnover, optimizing training and development, evaluating recruitment strategies, and identifying sources of pay inequity. Students will also receive training on ADP’s Workforce Now cloud-based Human Resource information system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of human resource analytics tools
Training on ADP’s Workforce Now cloud-based Human Resource information system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Optimization of HR processes through analytics
Data analysis for recruitment strategy evaluation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives for training and development optimization
Leading initiatives for pay inequity identification

courseDescription: The course examines organizational structure and functioning from cross-cultural and cross-national perspectives.  Compares how management practices differ from one society to another.  Comparisons are made between the U.S., Western Europe, Japan, the USSR, China, and the Third World nations.

A study tour abroad under the direction of a faculty member including on-site visits and management lectures designed to provide insight into differences in management practices in foreign countries.  Offered summers only and when available.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying foreign management practices

courseDescription: This is a course based on the SHRM (Society for Human Resource Management) Learning System® for SHRM-CP/SHRM-SCP. Comprised of comprehensive learning modules teaching the SHRM Body of Applied Skills and Knowledge™ (SHRM BASK™), and advanced online multimedia resources, these study materials streamline study time, accelerate learning and build confidence for passing the SHRM-CP/SHRM-SCP exam. The course tuition includes all books, including one year access to the SHRM online learning resources, but does not include registration for the SHRM-CP/SHRM-SCP examinations.
Technical and Digital Skills: SHRM Body of Applied Skills and Knowledge

courseDescription: Strategic management addresses the concerns of the high level executive or general manager, who must use a perspective that is qualitatively different from that of the lower-level functional manager or operations manager.  Strategic decisions cut across functional lines.  Whereas other courses focus on competency at a functional level (Are we doing things right?), this course deals with the overall effectiveness of the total organization (Are we doing the right things?).  This is a writing intensive course.

An exploration of the consulting industry and its role in driving improvements across various types of organizations. Students will learn problem-solving frameworks used to direct decision making as well as real-world communication and project management skills.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of consulting industry trends and tools

courseDescription: Designed to provide advanced students in management an opportunity to study administration in highly specialized areas under the guidance of a faculty member.
Designed to provide advanced students in management an opportunity for independent study of selected areas under the guidance of a faculty member.

An analysis of how the federal and state governments may regulate the employer-employee relationship. Topics include labor relations law, equal employment opportunity law, other current statutory employment law and common law employment issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of equal employment opportunity law
Comprehension of common law employment issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to negotiate and mediate in employment issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of federal and state regulations

courseDescription: This course focuses on negotiations and change. Students will develop analytical, interpersonal, and communication skills, with an emphasis placed on experiential learning through case studies, role playing, and simulations.

A study tour abroad under the direction of a faculty member including on-site visits and management lectures designed to provide insight into differences in management practices in foreign countries.  Offered summers only and when available.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of international management practices

courseDescription: Examine issues and principles in the management of individuals, groups, and organizations.  Topics include motivation and reward systems, groups dynamics and team building organization design and change.

This course focuses on providing students with the foundations of leadership by reviewing past leadership research and integrating this into their own understanding of what makes one an effective leader.  Contemporary concepts of leadership, including the role of culture and gender, will also be presented.  The course will utilize self-assessments, case analysis, and leadership-related readings that will require students to think critically about what leaders do and how their own strengths and limitations influence their personal leadership development.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking and analysis of leadership styles
Understanding and evaluating the role of culture and gender in leadership
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying contemporary leadership concepts

courseDescription: This course provides a critical analysis of organizational theories used to understand and predict employee attitudes and behaviors. Implications, in terms of applying theories to address management issues and optimize human resource practices, are evaluated. Topics include job satisfaction, motivation, stress, and decision making.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and predicting employee attitudes and behaviors

courseDescription: An analysis and evaluation of current human resource practices and problems. Examines topics such as human resource planning, selection, development, and compensation.

This course introduces students to the discipline of strategic management and discusses concepts/theories/frameworks that are used in the formulation and implementation of strategies.  Additionally, students discuss cases, simulation and examples that describe the strategic issues confronting organizations and how they successfully (or unsuccessfully) resolved them.  The course should help students develop a disciplined, rigorous, and comprehensive approach to analyzing firm environment and resources and formulating and implementing strategy.  In addition, the course should help students understand the challenges and common pitfalls involved in strategy formulation and implementation.

This course addresses how managers and organizations can enhance employee productivity and job satisfaction in a competitive global environment. Both the theories and practices of motivation and leadership will be examined.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational management in a global environment

courseDescription: This course is a practicum in management, applying theories, concepts, and management techniques in a business setting.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solution implementation based on management concepts

courseDescription: Study designed for students who have one or more of the required courses waived, or for students desiring additional work in an area of particular interest in management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Specialized knowledge in a particular management area
Ability to leverage management tools and software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a management context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills within a specific domain of management

courseDescription: This course deals with various strategic options available to businesses operating in an international environment. It explores the literature and case materials on multinational companies and the theories and concepts relevant to the analysis of international strategic decisions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of international business theories and concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in an international business context
Understanding and respecting cultural differences in international business
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and decision-making in international business strategy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning and organization in an international environment

courseDescription: A capstone integrative course on strategy formulation and implementation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in strategy formulation and implementation

courseDescription: This course deals with various strategic options available to businesses operating in an international environment.  It explores the literature and case materials on multinational companies and the theories and concepts relevant to the analysis of international strategic decisions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of case materials

courseDescription: The course examines strategic issues in human resource management.  The course will examine how strategies and policies in areas such as recruitment, selection, training, career development, performance management and international human resource management influence firm performance.  Other topics of current research may also be included.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cross-cultural communication for international human resource management
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for career development planning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for managing human resources

courseDescription: This course examines theories and empirical research on organizations and their environment.  Topics would include organization design, structure, decision making, change and adaptation.  Other topics of current research may also be included.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of decision-making processes in organizations
Familiarity with organizational change and adaptation strategies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and debate current research topics in organizational theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of empirical research on organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in organizational design and change

courseDescription: This course introduces strategic management students to the different theories, concepts, and phenomena in the field of corporate strategy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of strategic theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and application of corporate strategy theories

courseDescription: This course introduces a variety of explanations for organizational competitive advantage as the ultimate outcome of business strategy.   This course includes reading assignments, discussions and student presentations directed to developing novel research ideas.

This course critically evaluates the classical debates and viewpoints within strategic management research.  In addition the course would cover the emerging theoretical and methodological areas in strategic management research.  Finally, the course would review in depth the research on contemporary issues in strategy.  The objective of the course is to enable students to become independent scholars in the area of strategic management.
This doctoral seminar will expose students to the theory and research behind strategic entrepreneurship and prepare them to do rigorous and relevant research in this field of study.
Advanced study in selected topics in management planning, strategy and policy under the direction of one or more faculty in the Management Department.
Ph.D.-level research and writing of dissertation.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
